description: From Middle English supporten, from Old French supporter, from Latin supportō.

verbs.description: support (third-person singular simple present supports, present participle supporting, simple past and past participle supported)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To keep from falling.
examples: Don’t move that beam! It supports the whole platform.
Synonyms: bestand, stut, undergird, underprop, upbear, upgird, uphold

entries.meaning: (transitive) To answer questions and resolve problems regarding something sold.
examples: Sure they sell the product, but do they support it?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To back a cause, party, etc., mentally or with concrete aid.
examples: I support France in the World Cup.
Antonym: oppose

entries.meaning: (transitive) To help, particularly financially.
examples: The government supports the arts in several ways.

entries.meaning: To verify; to make good; to substantiate; to establish; to sustain.
examples: The testimony is not sufficient to support the charges.
The evidence will not support the statements or allegations.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To serve, as in a customer-oriented mindset; to give support to.
examples: The IT Department supports the research organization, but not the sales force.
I don't make decisions, but I support those who do.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be designed (said of machinery, electronics, or computers, or their parts, accessories, peripherals, or programming) to function compatibly with or provide the capacity for.
examples: Early personal computers did not support voice-recognition hardware or software.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be accountable for, or involved with, but not responsible for.
examples: I support the administrative activities of the executive branch of the organization.

entries.meaning: (archaic) To endure without being overcome; bear; undergo; to tolerate.
examples: This fierce demeanour and his insolence / The patience of a god could not support.

entries.meaning: To assume and carry successfully, as the part of an actor; to represent or act; to sustain.
examples: to support the character of King Lear

description: From Middle English support, from Anglo-Norman and Middle French support. Displaced Old English wraþu.

entries.meaning: (sometimes attributive) Something which supports.
examples: Don't move that beam! It's a support for the whole platform.

entries.meaning: Financial or other help.
examples: The government provides support to the arts in several ways.

entries.meaning: Answers to questions and resolution of problems regarding something sold.
examples: Sure they sell the product, but do they provide support?
Hyponyms: first-level support, second-level support, third-level support

entries.meaning: (mathematics) in relation to a function, the set of points where the function is not zero, or the closure of that set.
examples: Antonym: kernel

entries.meaning: (fuzzy set theory) A set whose elements are at least partially included in a given fuzzy set (i.e., whose grade of membership in that fuzzy set is strictly greater than zero).
examples: If the membership function of a fuzzy set is continuous, then that fuzzy set's support is an open set.

entries.meaning: Evidence.
examples: The new research provides further support for our theory.

entries.meaning: (computing) Compatibility and functionality for a given product or feature.
examples: This game has no mouse support.

entries.meaning: An actor playing a subordinate part with a star.
An accompaniment in music.
(gymnastics) Clipping of support position.
(structural analysis) Horizontal, vertical or rotational support of structures: movable, hinged, fixed.
